media.caption: This longhouse served as the communal living quarters for the families at Ceresco, the Fourierite commune in what is now Ripon, Wisconsin.
media.credit: From the Arthur E. Bestor Research Collection on Communitarianism (MS 468). Image courtesy of the Illinois History and Lincoln Collections, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign Library
media.thumb: This longhouse served as the communal living quarters for the families at Ceresco, the Fourierite commune in what is now Ripon, Wisconsin.

text.headline: Fourier Club organized in Southport (later Kenosha)
text.text: The mouth of the Pike River drew migrants rapidly in the 1830s and 1840s seeking to create a better society. A number of them, influenced by the thought of French utopian socialist Charles Fourier, founded a club dedicated to creating a society based on his ideas in 1843 and organized a "phalanx" (a communal living complex) in Fond du Lac county the following year. Notable members of the club include Charles Durkee, the first Republican member of the US Senate; Louis Harney, who would later become Governor; and Charles Latham Sholes, newspaper editor and inventor of the QWERTY keyboard. The commune disbanded in 1849.

media.caption: This scrapbook from George Brosius, a prominent Turner and gymnastics instructor in Milwaukee, discusses the formation and early years of the Milwaukee Turnverein.
media.credit: Special Collections, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries
media.thumb: This scrapbook from George Brosius, a prominent Turner and gymnastics instructor in Milwaukee, discusses the formation and early years of the Milwaukee Turnverein.

text.headline: Milwaukee Turner Society opens school
text.text: German immigrants to Milwaukee, particularly those who fled central Europe after the failed 1848 revolutions, organized gymnastics clubs called Turnvereine, or Turners. These clubs were dedicated to physical activity but also frequently served as incubators of German culture and progressive politics.

media.caption: Turners Hall and Robert Chivas Post Hall (Fourth Street between Prairie and State.)
media.credit: Special Collections, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries
media.thumb: Turners Hall and Robert Chivas Post Hall (Fourth Street between Prairie and State.)

text.headline: Turner Hall constructed
text.text: Turner Hall, constructed on North 4th Street in 1882, served as a center for Turner meetings in the city.

media.caption: Emil Seidel discusses the vereinigung (federation) that arose after 1886 in his unpublished autobiography.
media.thumb: Emil Seidel discusses the vereinigung (federation) that arose after 1886 in his unpublished autobiography.

text.text: Workers striking for an eight-hour work day including a large continent of Polish laborers from the North Chicago Rolling Mills facility in Bay View were fired upon by Wisconsin state troops acting on the orders of Governor Jeremiah Rusk, killing seven. The shootings were intended to quell the labor movement but instead galvanized support for it, leading to the consolidation of groups into a populist coalition -- the People's Party -- that won elections in the fall.

text.headline: 1886 elections
text.text: the People's Party wins most county office, half of MKE's state assembly seats, and Henry Smith wins seat in House of Representatives

media.caption: Emil Seidel recounts the story of Berger converting Debs to socialism while the latter was in prison in his autobiography.
media.thumb: Emil Seidel recounts the story of Berger converting Debs to socialism while the latter was in prison in his autobiography.

text.headline: formation of the Social Democracy of America party
text.text: see the

media.caption: In his autobiography Emil Seidel, who was one of the nine aldermen elected in 1904, lists the measures the Socialists introduced in their first year.
media.thumb: In his autobiography Emil Seidel, who was one of the nine aldermen elected in 1904, lists the measures the Socialists introduced in their first year.

text.headline: Social Democrats win seats in city government
text.text: In 1904 Socialists win some seats in Milwaukee government for the first time, bringing nine aldermen to the Common Council. They bring a zeal for reform with them, introducing 318 measures in their first year and 349 in the second.

media.caption: Photograph of the Seidel family from the mayor's autobiography. Emil Seidel is on the far right.
media.thumb: Photograph of the Seidel family from the mayor's autobiography. Emil Seidel is on the far right.

text.headline: 1910 Municipal Election
text.text: Emil Seidel heads a Socialist ticket that resoundingly defeats the traditional parties, seating socialists including himself, Charles Whitnall as City Treasurer, Daniel Webster Hoan as City Attorney, 21 of 35 aldermen, 10 of 16 county supervisors, and 2 judges.

media.caption: Emil Seidel retells the birth of the annual Christmas tree tradition in his autobiography.
media.thumb: Emil Seidel retells the birth of the annual Christmas tree tradition in his autobiography.

text.headline: Community Christmas Tree
text.text: In 1910 Mayor Seidel ordered the setting up of a Christmas tree for the city in the Court of Honor on Wisconsin Avenue. The city still has a community Christmas tree tradition to this day.

media.caption: This speech from Mayor Seidel in 1911 presages the Lighted School House initiative.
media.thumb: This speech from Mayor Seidel in 1911 presages the Lighted School House initiative.

text.headline: Lighted Schoolhouse Initiative
text.text: Mayor Seidel introduces the Lighted Schoolhouse initiative to provide quality after-school recreation to the city's young people. The program included arts and sports for children, trade skills for teenagers, and evening classes for adults, by 1913 including civics and English language courses to serve the city's immigrant population. Lighted Schoolhouse programs are still found today in schools across southeastern Wisconsin.

media.caption: News articles reacting to Dr. Rucker's appraisal of Milwaukee's water supply versus that of his successor, Dr. Frederick Kraft.
media.thumb: News articles reacting to Dr. Rucker's appraisal of Milwaukee's water supply versus that of his successor, Dr. Frederick Kraft.

text.headline: Typhoid Fever in Milwaukee
text.text: The new health commissioner, Dr. William Colby Rucker, identified Milwaukee's polluted water supply as causing an outbreak of typhoid and recommended a boil water order for the city until it can be chlorinated. This would be the beginning of the "sewer socialists'" eponymous work in improving Milwaukee's water and sewage systems.

media.caption: New articles discussing the construction of facilities in the city to treat tuberculosis.
media.thumb: New articles discussing the construction of facilities in the city to treat tuberculosis.

text.headline: Blue Mound Sanatarium opens
text.text: In 1911 the city opened the Blue Mound and Greenfield Sanatariums to treat individuals with tuberculosis, the first in the city.

media.caption: This proposal from the commission draws on its successes in the 14th ward to suggest establishing eleven child welfare stations throughout the city.
media.thumb: This proposal from the commission draws on its successes in the 14th ward to suggest establishing eleven child welfare stations throughout the city.

text.headline: Child Welfare Commission
text.text: The new mayor and Common Council established a commission to conduct an experimental outreach and treatment strategy in a section of the 14th ward to reduce infant mortality there. By connecting expecting and new mothers with health professionals, the commission succeeded at reducing the rate by 66%, leading to an expansion of the strategy throughout the city.

text.headline: Milwaukee Leader begins publication
text.text: The longest lasting socialist newspaper in the United States, the Milwaukee Leader was created by Victor Berger to present the party's point of view in the media. It was published six days a week and sold in 300 locations across the country. The Leader covered local, national, and international news, even including sports and comics.

media.caption: The Milwaukee Continuation School first began classes in 1912 in the Manufacturers' Home Building and here in the Stroh Building.
media.thumb: The Milwaukee Continuation School first began classes in 1912 in the Manufacturers' Home Building and here in the Stroh Building.

text.headline: Milwaukee Continuation School
text.text: Opened for classes in 1912, became the Milwaukee Area Technical College.

media.caption: Report on the hospital's history and status by the Committee on Public Health, 1918.
media.thumb: Report on the hospital's history and status by the Committee on Public Health, 1918.

text.headline: South View Hospital
text.text: Addressing a longterm need for a modern facility for the care of individuals with contagious diseases and at the pressing of the new health commissioners, the city constructed a new hospital in 1912, with an additional wing constructed in 1917.

media.caption: Pamphlet: "Defense of the Socialist Regime in Milwaukee," 1912. This lengthy treatise attempts to frame the election as the regular population vs. "the trusts, the monopolies, big business, gambling and vice, a servile press, grafters and bribe-givers together with those who allow themselves to be prejudiced by the interests."
media.thumb: Pamphlet: "Defense of the Socialist Regime in Milwaukee," 1912. This lengthy treatise attempts to frame the election as the regular population vs. "the trusts, the monopolies, big business, gambling and vice, a servile press, grafters and bribe-givers together with those who allow themselves to be prejudiced by the interests."

text.headline: Seidel unseated from mayor's office
text.text: A Democratic-Republican fusion ticket erased most of the socialists' gains from 1908 including the loss of Victor Berger's seat in Congress and Seidel being defeated by Gerhard Bading, former city health commissioner. Seidel would go for a rematch in 1914 but lose again, never returning to office.

media.caption: Seidel recounts the 1912 Socialist convention and campaign for president in his autobiography.
media.thumb: Seidel recounts the 1912 Socialist convention and campaign for president in his autobiography.

text.headline: 1912 Presidential Election
text.text: In the 1912 election Emil Seidel ran as Eugene Debs' running mate on the Socialist Party ticket against incumbent Republican William Howard Taft, Democrat Woodrow Wilson, and Progressive "Bull Moose" candidate Theodore Roosevelt. The Debs-Seidel ticket won 901,551 votes (6% of the vote).

media.caption: Flyer: "Bring in the Wheat," 1914.
media.thumb: Flyer: "Bring in the Wheat," 1914.

media.caption: A warm letter from Dan Hoan to Emil Seidel in 1940.
media.thumb: A warm letter from Dan Hoan to Emil Seidel in 1940.

text.headline: Daniel Hoan becomes mayor
text.text: Dan Hoan defeated Gerhard Bading by a mere 1500 votes, becoming the city's second socialist mayor. Hoan's tenure in the mayor's office would be considerably longer than his predecessor's, lasting 24 years

media.caption: Report of Executive Summary on Emergency National Convention, 1917. Here Victor Berger and others propose to President Wilson embargoing all warring European countries as a way to force an end to the war.
media.thumb: Report of Executive Summary on Emergency National Convention, 1917. Here Victor Berger and others propose to President Wilson embargoing all warring European countries as a way to force an end to the war.

text.headline: Socialist party opposes US involvement in World War I
text.text: The Socialist Party in the United States opposed the war in Europe and tried to keep the United States neutral. As support for the Allied Powers became dominant in the US, socialists became the targets of invective in press, violence, and even prosecution.

media.caption: This letter to subscribers of the Leader urges them to purchase bonds to preserve the paper.
media.thumb: This letter to subscribers of the Leader urges them to purchase bonds to preserve the paper.

text.headline: Milwaukee Leader loses second-class mail privileges
text.text: In compliance with the Espionage Act passed earlier that summer, the Third Assistant Postmaster General instructed the Milwaukee office to no longer entitle the Leader to second-class postage rates, denying it a national reach and access to some 40% of its readership.

media.caption: Victor L. Berger, undated.
media.credit: Harris & Ewing photograph collection, Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division
media.thumb: Victor L. Berger, undated.

text.headline: Berger Indicted
text.text: As part of the federal government's effort to sideline anti-war voices, Victor Berger and four other Socialists were tried and convicted of sedition for violations of the new Espionage Act and were sentenced to twenty years in prison.

text.headline: Daniel Hoan wins re-election
text.text: The Milwaukee electorate reacts to the Berger indictment by re-electing its Socialist mayor and adding another to the Common Council.

media.caption: Socialist Party State Platform, 1923. This pamphlet points triumphantly to Berger's re-election multiple times after Congress refused to seat him due to being indicted for sedition.
media.thumb: Socialist Party State Platform, 1923. This pamphlet points triumphantly to Berger's re-election multiple times after Congress refused to seat him due to being indicted for sedition.

text.headline: Socialists sweep Milwaukee elections
text.text: Milwaukeeans elect every Socialist in Milwaukee County elections, including now-indicted Victor Berger back to his congressional seat.

text.headline: Garden Homes built
text.text: In 1921 the city broke down on a cooperative urban housing development to combat its housing shortage. 93 houses were built just outside the city limits whose tenants paid into the homes' own non-profit corporation. Emil Seidel was one of the first tenants. Tenants voted to dissolve the co-op in 1925, anticipating that they could make money by taking advantage of rising real estate values. Many lost their investments and homes when the stock market crashed in 1929.

media.caption: View of the sewage treatment plant. The Jones Island plant started treating waste in 1925 and was expanded in 1934 and 1952. The plant is listed in the National Register of Historic Places.
media.credit: American Geographical Society Library, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries
media.thumb: View of the sewage treatment plant. The Jones Island plant started treating waste in 1925 and was expanded in 1934 and 1952. The plant is listed in the National Register of Historic Places.

text.headline: Construction of Jones Island Water Treatment Plant
text.text: This plant deals with sewerage disposal, solving the problem of the rivers and bay being polluted by sewerage causing periodic outbreaks of intestinal diseases.

media.caption: A postcard showing the Botanical Gardens Administration Building at Charles Whitnall Park, one of the many parks around the city Whitnall created.
media.thumb: A postcard showing the Botanical Gardens Administration Building at Charles Whitnall Park, one of the many parks around the city Whitnall created.

text.headline: Charles Whitnall's Parks Master Plan
text.text: A florist by trade, Charles Whitnall served as charter member of the county Parks Commission from its inception in 1907 until 1941. He envisioned a system of parks and highways throughout the city mitigating congestion and pollution and surrounding the citizens with nature. In 1923 drew up his plans and, through his role in county government and the enactment of the nation's first county zoning ordinances in 1927, he began making them a reality piece by piece, including Grant, Estabrook, and Brown Deer parks as well as Lincoln Memorial Drive.

media.caption: Emil Seidel gives a history lesson in the saga of water conditions and treatment in Milwaukee in his autobiography.
media.thumb: Emil Seidel gives a history lesson in the saga of water conditions and treatment in Milwaukee in his autobiography.

text.headline: Construction of the Linnwood Water Treatment Plant
text.text: This plant filters city water, finally ending the "stopgap" measure of chlorinating the water that Dr. Rucker had begun some 27 years prior. Mayor Seidel, an alderman at the time of construction, estimates that some 300 city resolutions were required to complete construction of the plant.

media.caption: Frank Zeidler is being interviewed about his decision not to seek a fourth term as mayor of Milwaukee.
media.credit: Archives. University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. Copyright WTMJ-TV.
media.thumb: Frank Zeidler is being interviewed about his decision not to seek a fourth term as mayor of Milwaukee.

text.headline: Frank Zeidler elected mayor
text.text: Frank Paul Zeidler, brother of recently deceased mayor Carl Zeidler, was elected governor in 1948, the last Socialist to hold the office. Zeidler presided over the doubling of the city's footprint, the establishment of the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, and the upscaling of the city's highway infrastructure.

media.caption: Aerial view of campus looking east towards Lake Michigan, ca. 1961.
media.thumb: Aerial view of campus looking east towards Lake Michigan, ca. 1961.

text.headline: creation of the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee
text.text: Mayor Zeidler pushed for the establishment of a public university in the city, which finally came in 1956 via a merger of the Wisconsin State Teachers College, Milwaukee and the University of Wisconsin’s Milwaukee Extension Division. The new university was placed under the purview of the University of Wisconsin at Madison and quickly grew to become of one of the largest universities in the state.

text.headline: creation of WMVS-TV (PBS Channel 10)
text.text: In 1957 Mayor Zeidler backed the establishment of Wisconsin's second public television station over the protests of local network TV affiliates. It was designated WMVS to denote its ownership by the Milwaukee Vocational School (now Milwaukee Area Technical College). It was used by Milwaukee Public Schools and the Catholic Archdiocese for education, and expanded into a second station, WMVT-TV, in 1963. Today Milwaukee PBS operates seven channels in southeast Wisconsin.

media.caption: Full text of Zeidler Report
media.thumb: Full text of Zeidler Report

text.headline: Release of the Zeidler Report
text.text: Frank Zeidler's last act as mayor was to release the "Mayor’s Study Committee on Social Problems in the Inner Core Area of the City," a study of the north side neighborhoods most economically stressed that documented issues such as racial segregation in housing. These neighborhoods between Keefe and Juneau Avenues, and 20th and Holton Streets, were analyzed by the committee in tandem with faculty and graduate students in UWM's School of Social Work. While the Zeidler Report blamed some of the Inner Core's ills on the residents' "cultural deficiencies," it also detailed housing segregation, lack of community resources and facilities, and poor relations between the residents and the police. Alderperson and civil rights icon Vel Phillips prevented the Common Council from burying the report.

text.headline: Milwaukee Public Museum opens
text.text: From 1898 until 1962 Central Library on Wisconsin Avenue also housed the Milwaukee Public Museum, constraining both institutions. Frank Zeidler secured funding and construction of a new space for the museum across Wells Street where it resides today.
